query: How soon must an organisation notify the PDPC after deciding a breach is notifiable?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Where an organisation assesses, in accordance with section 26C, that a data breach is a notifiable data breach, the organisation must notify the Commission as soon as is practicable, but in any case no later than 3 calendar days after the day the organisation makes that assessment.

query: Who must be informed after the PDPC has been notified of a notifiable breach?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subject to subsections (5), (6) and (7), on or after notifying the Commission under subsection (1), the organisation must also notify each affected individual affected by a notifiable data breach mentioned in section 26B(1)(a) in any manner that is reasonable in the circumstances.

query: What details must be included in a PDPA data breach notification?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
The notification under subsection (1) or (2) must contain, to the best of the knowledge and belief of the organisation at the time it notifies the Commission or affected individual (as the case may be), all the information that is prescribed for this purpose.

query: How must a company submit a data breach notification to the PDPC?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
The notification under subsection (1) must be made in the form and submitted in the manner required by the Commission.

query: When can a company skip notifying affected individuals about a breach?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsection (2) does not apply to an organisation in relation to an affected individual if the organisation —
(a) on or after assessing that the data breach is a notifiable data breach, takes any action, in accordance with any prescribed requirements, that renders it unlikely that the notifiable data breach will result in significant harm to the affected individual; or
(b) had implemented, prior to the occurrence of the notifiable data breach, any technological measure that renders it unlikely that the notifiable data breach will result in significant harm to the affected individual.

query: Can the police stop a company from informing individuals about a breach?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
An organisation must not notify any affected individual in accordance with subsection (2) if —
(a) a prescribed law enforcement agency so instructs; or
(b) the Commission so directs.

query: Can an organisation apply to the PDPC to waive notifying individuals?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
The Commission may, on the written application of an organisation, waive the requirement to notify an affected individual under subsection (2) subject to any conditions that the Commission thinks fit.

query: Does reporting a breach violate confidentiality or secrecy laws?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
An organisation is not, by reason only of notifying the Commission under subsection (1) or an affected individual under subsection (2), to be regarded as being in breach of —
(a) any duty or obligation under any written law or rule of law, or any contract, as to secrecy or other restriction on the disclosure of information; or
(b) any rule of professional conduct applicable to the organisation.

query: If another law also requires data breach reporting, does PDPA still apply?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsections (1) and (2) apply concurrently with any obligation of the organisation under any other written law to notify any other person (including any public agency) of the occurrence of a data breach, or to provide any information relating to a data breach.
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency

query: What protection does a company have when disclosing information during a breach notification?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
An organisation is not, by reason only of notifying the Commission under subsection (1) or an affected individual under subsection (2), to be regarded as being in breach of —
(a) any duty or obligation under any written law or rule of law, or any contract, as to secrecy or other restriction on the disclosure of information; or
(b) any rule of professional conduct applicable to the organisation.

query: If the PDPC waives notification, can it impose conditions?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
The Commission may, on the written application of an organisation, waive the requirement to notify an affected individual under subsection (2) subject to any conditions that the Commission thinks fit.

query: What if an organisation provides incomplete information when notifying a breach?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
The notification under subsection (1) or (2) must contain, to the best of the knowledge and belief of the organisation at the time it notifies the Commission or affected individual (as the case may be), all the information that is prescribed for this purpose.

query: Can PDPA notification duties overlap with those under other regulations, like banking laws?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsections (1) and (2) apply concurrently with any obligation of the organisation under any other written law to notify any other person (including any public agency) of the occurrence of a data breach, or to provide any information relating to a data breach.
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency

query: Can a company choose not to notify the PDPC if it already reported to another agency?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsections (1) and (2) apply concurrently with any obligation of the organisation under any other written law to notify any other person (including any public agency) of the occurrence of a data breach, or to provide any information relating to a data breach.
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency

query: If an organisation takes steps that eliminate harm risk, must it still notify affected individuals?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsection (2) does not apply to an organisation in relation to an affected individual if the organisation —
(a) on or after assessing that the data breach is a notifiable data breach, takes any action, in accordance with any prescribed requirements, that renders it unlikely that the notifiable data breach will result in significant harm to the affected individual; or
(b) had implemented, prior to the occurrence of the notifiable data breach, any technological measure that renders it unlikely that the notifiable data breach will result in significant harm to the affected individual.

query: What if the PDPC directs that individuals should not be notified, but the company believes they should?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
An organisation must not notify any affected individual in accordance with subsection (2) if —
(a) a prescribed law enforcement agency so instructs; or
(b) the Commission so directs.

query: Can an organisation face penalties for reporting a breach if it reveals confidential business data?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
An organisation is not, by reason only of notifying the Commission under subsection (1) or an affected individual under subsection (2), to be regarded as being in breach of —
(a) any duty or obligation under any written law or rule of law, or any contract, as to secrecy or other restriction on the disclosure of information; or
(b) any rule of professional conduct applicable to the organisation.

query: If a company isn’t sure whether its remedial actions removed harm risk, must it still notify individuals?
pos_texts:
Duty to notify occurrence of notifiable data breach
Subsection (2) does not apply to an organisation in relation to an affected individual if the organisation —
(a) on or after assessing that the data breach is a notifiable data breach, takes any action, in accordance with any prescribed requirements, that renders it unlikely that the notifiable data breach will result in significant harm to the affected individual; or

query: Can employees be held personally liable for sending DNC messages if they were following company orders?
pos_texts:
Defence for employee
In any proceedings for an offence under this Part brought against any employee in respect of an act or conduct alleged to have been done or engaged in (as the case may be) by the employee, it is a defence for the employee to prove that he or she did the act or engaged in the conduct in good faith —
(a) in the course of his or her employment; or
(b) in accordance with instructions given to him or her by or on behalf of his or her employer in the course of his or her employment.

query: Does the DNC rule in section 43(1) apply to employees acting in good faith?
pos_texts:
Defence for employee
Section 43(1) or 44 does not apply to an employee (X) who sends a specified message addressed to a Singapore telephone number in good faith —
(a) in the course of X’s employment; or
(b) in accordance with instructions given to X by or on behalf of X’s employer in the course of X’s employment.

query: Can an employee hide caller IDs if told to by the employer?
pos_texts:
Defence for employee
Section 45 does not apply to an employee (Y) who makes, causes to be made or authorises the making of a voice call containing a specified message, addressed to a Singapore telephone number, from a telephone number or fax number, in good faith —
(a) in the course of Y’s employment; or
(b) in accordance with instructions given to Y by or on behalf of Y’s employer in the course of Y’s employment.

query: When does the employee defence under section 48 not apply?
pos_texts:
Defence for employee
Subsection (1), (2) or (3) does not apply to an employee (Z) who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was an officer or a partner of Z’s employer and it is proved that —
(a) Z knew or ought reasonably to have known that the telephone number is a Singapore telephone number listed in the relevant register; and
(b) the specified message was sent with Z’s consent or connivance, or the sending of the specified message was attributable to any neglect on Z’s part.

query: What do 'officer' and 'partner' mean under section 48?
pos_texts:
Defence for employee
In this section —
“corporation” has the meaning given by section 52(7);
“officer”  —
(a) in relation to a corporation, has the meaning given by section 52(7); or
(b) in relation to an unincorporated association (other than a partnership), has the meaning given by section 52A(7);
“partner”, in relation to a partnership, has the meaning given by section 52A(7).

query: What can the PDPC issue to help organisations understand how it interprets the PDPA?
pos_texts:
Advisory guidelines
The Commission may issue written advisory guidelines indicating the manner in which the Commission will interpret the provisions of this Act.

query: Can the PDPC change its advisory guidelines once published?
pos_texts:
Advisory guidelines
Guidelines issued under this section may be varied, amended or revoked by the Commission.

query: Does failure to publish PDPC advisory guidelines properly make them invalid?
pos_texts:
Advisory guidelines
The Commission must publish the guidelines in any way the Commission thinks fit, but failure to comply with this subsection in respect of any guidelines does not invalidate the guidelines.
Powers of investigation

query: Are advisory guidelines legally binding on organisations?
pos_texts:
Advisory guidelines
The Commission may issue written advisory guidelines indicating the manner in which the Commission will interpret the provisions of this Act.

query: When must an organisation get my consent before collecting or using my personal data?
pos_texts:
Consent required
An organisation must not, on or after 2 July 2014, collect, use or disclose personal data about an individual unless —
(a) the individual gives, or is deemed to have given, his or her consent under this Act to the collection, use or disclosure, as the case may be; or
(b) the collection, use or disclosure (as the case may be) without the individual’s consent is required or authorised under this Act or any other written law.
Provision of consent

query: What happens if an organisation refuses to give me my personal data under section 21?
pos_texts:
Preservation of copies of personal data
Where —
(a) an individual, on or after 1 February 2021, makes a request under section 21(1)(a) to an organisation to provide personal data about the individual that is in the possession or under the control of the organisation; and
(b) the organisation refuses to provide that personal data,
the organisation must preserve, for not less than the prescribed period, a copy of the personal data concerned.

query: Must the preserved copy of data be complete and accurate?
pos_texts:
Preservation of copies of personal data
The organisation must ensure that the copy of the personal data it preserves for the purposes of subsection (1) is a complete and accurate copy of the personal data concerned.

query: Does the preservation rule apply to correction requests too?
pos_texts:
Preservation of copies of personal data
Where —
(a) an individual, on or after 1 February 2021, makes a request under section 21(1)(a) to an organisation to provide personal data about the individual that is in the possession or under the control of the organisation; and
(b) the organisation refuses to provide that personal data,
the organisation must preserve, for not less than the prescribed period, a copy of the personal data concerned.

query: How can I prove whether the company kept a complete preserved copy of my data?
pos_texts:
Preservation of copies of personal data
The organisation must ensure that the copy of the personal data it preserves for the purposes of subsection (1) is a complete and accurate copy of the personal data concerned.

query: Does a company have to keep the preserved copy forever after refusing access?
pos_texts:
Preservation of copies of personal data
Where —
(a) an individual, on or after 1 February 2021, makes a request under section 21(1)(a) to an organisation to provide personal data about the individual that is in the possession or under the control of the organisation; and
(b) the organisation refuses to provide that personal data,
the organisation must preserve, for not less than the prescribed period, a copy of the personal data concerned.

query: Before imposing a direction or financial penalty, what notice must PDPC give?
How long must organisations or persons have to make representations before a financial penalty?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission intends to impose a financial penalty under section 48J(1) on an organisation or a person, the time specified in the notice within which written representations may be made to the Commission must be at least 14 days after the date the notice is served on that organisation or person.

query: Can the time to submit written representations be extended?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may, on written application by the organisation or person concerned (whether before, on or after the expiry of the time specified in the notice), extend the time for the organisation or person to make written representations to the Commission if the Commission is satisfied that the extension should be granted by reason of exceptional circumstances in the particular case.

query: When can PDPC proceed to issue a direction or impose a penalty?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may decide to give the direction under section 48I or impose the financial penalty under section 48J(1), as the case may be —
(a) after considering any written representation made to the Commission pursuant to the notice mentioned in subsection (1); or
(b) upon the expiry of the time specified in the notice under subsection (1)(d), or as extended by the Commission under subsection (3), where no representation is so made or any written representation made is subsequently withdrawn.

query: Is notice required if the subject has ceased to exist?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Subsection (1) does not apply where the organisation or person (as the case may be) has died, is adjudged bankrupt, has been dissolved or wound up or has otherwise ceased to exist.

query: Who must be notified once PDPC decides to give a direction or impose a penalty?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission decides to give the direction under section 48I or impose the financial penalty under section 48J(1) (as the case may be), the Commission must serve a notice of the decision on the following persons:
(a) the organisation or person concerned;
(b) the complainant whose complaint against the organisation or person concerned resulted in the giving of the direction or the imposition of the financial penalty (as the case may be), if any.

query: When does a PDPC direction or penalty take effect?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
A direction given under section 48I or the imposition of a financial penalty under section 48J(1) takes effect only when the Commission serves the notice in subsection (6)(a) on the organisation or person concerned.

query: How soon must a financial penalty be paid after PDPC’s notice?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission imposes a financial penalty under section 48J(1) on an organisation or a person, the written notice issued by the Commission to the organisation or person must specify the date before which the financial penalty is to be paid, being a date not earlier than 28 days after the notice is issued.

query: Can PDPC allow instalments or extend time to pay a penalty?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may, on written application by an organisation or a person on whom a financial penalty under section 48J(1) is imposed —
(a) extend the time for the organisation or person to pay the financial penalty; or
(b) allow the financial penalty to be paid by instalments.

query: What interest rate can PDPC impose on late or instalment payments of penalties?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The interest payable —
(a) on the outstanding amount of any financial penalty imposed under section 48J(1); and
(b) for payment by instalments (as the Commission may allow) of any financial penalty imposed under section 48J(1),
must be at such rate as the Commission may direct, which must not exceed the rate prescribed in the Rules of Court in respect of judgment debts.
Voluntary undertakings

query: If we miss the 14-day representation period, can we still ask for more time?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may, on written application by the organisation or person concerned (whether before, on or after the expiry of the time specified in the notice), extend the time for the organisation or person to make written representations to the Commission if the Commission is satisfied that the extension should be granted by reason of exceptional circumstances in the particular case.

query: Does PDPC have to notify the complainant of every decision to penalise or direct?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission decides to give the direction under section 48I or impose the financial penalty under section 48J(1) (as the case may be), the Commission must serve a notice of the decision on the following persons:
(a) the organisation or person concerned;
(b) the complainant whose complaint against the organisation or person concerned resulted in the giving of the direction or the imposition of the financial penalty (as the case may be), if any.

query: Can PDPC set a payment deadline of 14 days for a penalty if circumstances are urgent?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may, on written application by an organisation or a person on whom a financial penalty under section 48J(1) is imposed —
(a) extend the time for the organisation or person to pay the financial penalty; or
(b) allow the financial penalty to be paid by instalments.

Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission imposes a financial penalty under section 48J(1) on an organisation or a person, the written notice issued by the Commission to the organisation or person must specify the date before which the financial penalty is to be paid, being a date not earlier than 28 days after the notice is issued.

query: What happens if an entity is dissolved after the notice of intention but before the decision?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Subsection (1) does not apply where the organisation or person (as the case may be) has died, is adjudged bankrupt, has been dissolved or wound up or has otherwise ceased to exist.

query: When exactly does a PDPC decision become legally effective—on issue or on service?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
A direction given under section 48I or the imposition of a financial penalty under section 48J(1) takes effect only when the Commission serves the notice in subsection (6)(a) on the organisation or person concerned.

query: Can the complainant make representations in response to a penalty intention notice?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission intends to impose a financial penalty under section 48J(1) on an organisation or a person, the time specified in the notice within which written representations may be made to the Commission must be at least 14 days after the date the notice is served on that organisation or person.

Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
Where the Commission decides to give the direction under section 48I or impose the financial penalty under section 48J(1) (as the case may be), the Commission must serve a notice of the decision on the following persons:
(a) the organisation or person concerned;
(b) the complainant whose complaint against the organisation or person concerned resulted in the giving of the direction or the imposition of the financial penalty (as the case may be), if any.

query: Does PDPC have to list every specific non-compliance in the intention notice?
If we receive a notice proposing a direction (not a fine), must PDPC still allow time to make representations?
Can PDPC rely on interest to encourage timely payment of penalties by instalments?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The interest payable —
(a) on the outstanding amount of any financial penalty imposed under section 48J(1); and
(b) for payment by instalments (as the Commission may allow) of any financial penalty imposed under section 48J(1),
must be at such rate as the Commission may direct, which must not exceed the rate prescribed in the Rules of Court in respect of judgment debts.
Voluntary undertakings

query: What if no representations are made by the deadline—must PDPC still wait to decide?
pos_texts:
Procedure for giving of directions and imposing of financial penalty
The Commission may decide to give the direction under section 48I or impose the financial penalty under section 48J(1), as the case may be —
(a) after considering any written representation made to the Commission pursuant to the notice mentioned in subsection (1); or
(b) upon the expiry of the time specified in the notice under subsection (1)(d), or as extended by the Commission under subsection (3), where no representation is so made or any written representation made is subsequently withdrawn.

query: What must a data intermediary of a public agency do when it discovers a breach?
pos_texts:
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency
Where an organisation —
(a) is a data intermediary processing personal data on behalf of and for the purposes of a public agency; and
(b) has reason to believe that a data breach has occurred in relation to that personal data,
the organisation must, without undue delay, notify the public agency of the occurrence of the data breach.

query: How fast must a public agency’s data intermediary report a breach?
pos_texts:
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency
Where an organisation —
(a) is a data intermediary processing personal data on behalf of and for the purposes of a public agency; and
(b) has reason to believe that a data breach has occurred in relation to that personal data,
the organisation must, without undue delay, notify the public agency of the occurrence of the data breach.

query: If a data intermediary for a public agency doesn’t notify promptly, who is accountable?
pos_texts:
Obligations of data intermediary of public agency
Where an organisation —
(a) is a data intermediary processing personal data on behalf of and for the purposes of a public agency; and
(b) has reason to believe that a data breach has occurred in relation to that personal data,
the organisation must, without undue delay, notify the public agency of the occurrence of the data breach.

query: Can a company require customers to consent to marketing messages to receive goods or services?
pos_texts:
Consent
A person must not, as a condition for supplying goods, services, land, interest or opportunity, require a subscriber or user of a Singapore telephone number to give consent for the sending of a specified message to that Singapore telephone number or any other Singapore telephone number beyond what is reasonable to provide the goods, services, land, interest or opportunity to that subscriber or user, and any consent given in such circumstance is not validly given.

query: Is consent obtained through deception valid?
pos_texts:
Consent
If a person obtains or attempts to obtain consent for sending a specified message to a Singapore telephone number —
(a) by providing false or misleading information with respect to the sending of the specified message; or
(b) by using deceptive or misleading practices,
any consent given in such circumstances is not validly given.
Withdrawal of consent

query: What is the penalty for a PDPA offence that has no specific punishment stated in the Act?
pos_texts:
General penalties
A person guilty of an offence under this Act for which no penalty is expressly provided shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or to both and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine not exceeding $1,000 for every day or part of a day during which the offence continues after conviction.
Public servants and public officers

query: If someone keeps breaching the PDPA after conviction, can additional fines be imposed each day?
pos_texts:
General penalties
A person guilty of an offence under this Act for which no penalty is expressly provided shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years or to both and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine not exceeding $1,000 for every day or part of a day during which the offence continues after conviction.
Public servants and public officers

query: What types of complaints can the PDPC review when a person applies?
What can PDPC order after reviewing a complaint?
pos_texts:
Power to review
Upon completion of its review under subsection (1), the Commission may —
(a) confirm the refusal to provide access to the personal data or other information, or direct the organisation to provide access to the personal data or other information within the time specified by the Commission;
(b) confirm the refusal to correct the personal data, or direct the organisation to correct the personal data in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission;
(c) confirm the refusal to transmit the applicable data, or direct the porting organisation to transmit the applicable data in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission; or
(d) confirm, reduce or disallow a fee, or direct the organisation or porting organisation (as the case may be) to make a refund to the complainant or receiving organisation, as the case may be.
Directions for non compliance

query: Is a certificate confirming whether a number was on the DNC Register valid evidence in court?
pos_texts:
Evidence
A certificate purporting to be signed by the Chief Executive of the Authority or an authorised officer and stating that a Singapore telephone number was or was not listed in a register at a date specified in the certificate is admissible as evidence of its contents in any proceedings.
Information on terminated Singapore telephone number

query: What is the Data Protection Appeal Panel?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
There is established a Data Protection Appeal Panel.

query: Who appoints members of the Data Protection Appeal Panel?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
The Minister must appoint the members of the Appeal Panel.

query: Who appoints the Chairperson of the Appeal Panel?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
The Chairperson of the Appeal Panel must be appointed by the Minister from among the members of the Appeal Panel.

query: Who actually hears PDPA appeals and how many members are required?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
For the purpose of hearing any appeal under section 48Q, the Chairperson of the Appeal Panel may nominate a Data Protection Appeal Committee comprising 3 or more members of the Appeal Panel.

query: Where are the rules on Appeal Panel and Committee proceedings set out?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
The Seventh Schedule has effect with respect to the Appeal Panel, Appeal Committees and their members and the proceedings of Appeal Committees, as the case may be.
Appeal from direction or decision of Commission

query: Can the Chair nominate fewer than three members to hear an appeal?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
For the purpose of hearing any appeal under section 48Q, the Chairperson of the Appeal Panel may nominate a Data Protection Appeal Committee comprising 3 or more members of the Appeal Panel.

query: Who convenes the Appeal Committee to hear a PDPA appeal?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
For the purpose of hearing any appeal under section 48Q, the Chairperson of the Appeal Panel may nominate a Data Protection Appeal Committee comprising 3 or more members of the Appeal Panel.

query: Does the excerpt specify the detailed procedures of the Seventh Schedule for appeals?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
The Seventh Schedule has effect with respect to the Appeal Panel, Appeal Committees and their members and the proceedings of Appeal Committees, as the case may be.
Appeal from direction or decision of Commission

query: Can the Chair of the Appeal Panel choose committee members from outside the Panel?
pos_texts:
Data Protection Appeal Panel and Data Protection Appeal Committees
For the purpose of hearing any appeal under section 48Q, the Chairperson of the Appeal Panel may nominate a Data Protection Appeal Committee comprising 3 or more members of the Appeal Panel.

query: What is 'address harvesting software' under the PDPA?
What is a 'dictionary attack' in the context of marketing messages?
When does an 'applicable message' have a Singapore link?
Does it matter if the message never reaches its intended destination when determining if it’s an applicable message?
pos_texts:
Interpretation of this Part
For the purposes of the definition of “applicable message” in subsection (1), it does not matter —
(a) whether the telephone number to which the message is sent is a Singapore telephone number;
(b) whether that telephone number exists; or
(c) whether the message reaches its intended destination.

query: If a terminated number receives an undeliverable message, could it still have a Singapore link?
Is a telecom provider treated as the sender of an automated spam if it only carried the traffic?
pos_texts:
Interpretation of this Part
For the purposes of this Part, a telecommunications service provider that merely provides a service that enables an applicable message to be sent is, unless the contrary is proved, presumed not to have sent, caused to be sent or authorised the sending of the applicable message.

query: If my Wi-Fi was hijacked and messages were sent without my knowledge, am I responsible?
pos_texts:
Interpretation of this Part
For the purposes of this Part, if, at the time an applicable message is sent, the telecommunications device, service or network from which it was sent was controlled by a person without the knowledge of the owner or authorised user of the telecommunications device, service or network (as the case may be), the owner or authorised user (as the case may be) is, unless the contrary is proved, presumed not to have sent, caused to be sent or authorised the sending of the applicable message.

query: What counts as “control” over a device or network in this context?
pos_texts:
Interpretation of this Part
In subsection (5), “control” means —
(a) physical control; or
(b) control through the use of software or other means.
Prohibition on use of dictionary attacks and address harvesting software

query: Who is responsible for ensuring an organisation follows the PDPA?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must designate one or more individuals to be responsible for ensuring that the organisation complies with this Act.

query: Can the person responsible for PDPA compliance delegate their duties?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An individual designated under subsection (3) may delegate to another individual the responsibility conferred by that designation.

query: If a company appoints a Data Protection Officer, is it still responsible for data breaches?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
The designation of an individual by an organisation under subsection (3) does not relieve the organisation of any of its obligations under this Act.
Policies and practices

query: What must an organisation make public about its Data Protection Officer?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must make available to the public the business contact information of at least one of the individuals designated under subsection (3) or delegated under subsection (4).

query: How can an organisation be deemed to have fulfilled its duty to publish the Data Protection Officer’s contact information?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
Without limiting subsection (5), an organisation is deemed to have satisfied that subsection if the organisation makes available the business contact information of any individual mentioned in subsection (3) in any prescribed manner.

query: Who is ultimately responsible for personal data held by a company?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation is responsible for personal data in its possession or under its control.

query: What standard must an organisation follow when meeting its PDPA obligations?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
In meeting its responsibilities under this Act, an organisation must consider what a reasonable person would consider appropriate in the circumstances.

query: If a small business has very limited staff, must it still appoint a Data Protection Officer?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must designate one or more individuals to be responsible for ensuring that the organisation complies with this Act.

query: If an organisation outsources its customer database, is it still liable under the PDPA?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation is responsible for personal data in its possession or under its control.

query: How does the PDPA ensure that organisations act reasonably when applying its rules?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
In meeting its responsibilities under this Act, an organisation must consider what a reasonable person would consider appropriate in the circumstances.

query: Does the PDPA specify how the DPO’s contact details must be published?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
Without limiting subsection (5), an organisation is deemed to have satisfied that subsection if the organisation makes available the business contact information of any individual mentioned in subsection (3) in any prescribed manner.

query: If an organisation has multiple offices, must each one have its own DPO?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must designate one or more individuals to be responsible for ensuring that the organisation complies with this Act.

query: What happens if a company fails to provide its DPO’s contact information to the public?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must make available to the public the business contact information of at least one of the individuals designated under subsection (3) or delegated under subsection (4).

query: If a company publishes outdated DPO contact details, is it compliant?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation must make available to the public the business contact information of at least one of the individuals designated under subsection (3) or delegated under subsection (4).

query: If a company has data stored overseas but managed locally, which entity is responsible under PDPA?
pos_texts:
Compliance with Act
An organisation is responsible for personal data in its possession or under its control.

query: When is a data breach considered notifiable?
pos_texts:
Notifiable data breaches
A data breach is a notifiable data breach if the data breach —
(a) results in, or is likely to result in, significant harm to an affected individual; or
(b) is, or is likely to be, of a significant scale.

query: What type of personal data automatically triggers significant harm if breached?
pos_texts:
Notifiable data breaches
Without limiting subsection (1)(a), a data breach is deemed to result in significant harm to an individual —
(a) if the data breach is in relation to any prescribed personal data or class of personal data relating to the individual; or
(b) in other prescribed circumstances.

query: When is a data breach considered large enough to be of a significant scale?
pos_texts:
Notifiable data breaches
Without limiting subsection (1)(b), a data breach is deemed to be of a significant scale —
(a) if the data breach affects not fewer than the prescribed number of affected individuals; or
(b) in other prescribed circumstances.

query: If a breach happens only inside an organisation, must it be notified?
pos_texts:
Notifiable data breaches
Despite subsections (1), (2) and (3), a data breach that relates to the unauthorised access, collection, use, disclosure, copying or modification of personal data only within an organisation is deemed not to be a notifiable data breach.
Duty to conduct assessment of data breach

query: Who must be informed if a data breach affects thousands of customers?
pos_texts:
Notifiable data breaches
A data breach is a notifiable data breach if the data breach —
(a) results in, or is likely to result in, significant harm to an affected individual; or
(b) is, or is likely to be, of a significant scale.

Notifiable data breaches
A data breach is a notifiable data breach if the data breach —
(a) results in, or is likely to result in, significant harm to an affected individual; or
(b) is, or is likely to be, of a significant scale.
